case_title: SAADI ASMATULLAH vs INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT BANK OF PAKISTAN And 4 Other
complaint_summary: The appellant objected to the attachment of property Khasra No. 4741/5.4, claiming to be a bona fide purchaser for value.
investigation_summary: The appellant presented evidence of sale deeds and testified to having consulted Revenue Records and the Sub-Registrar's office. The bank admitted the mortgage was not registered, and its details were not entered in official records.
judgment_summary: The court accepted the appeal, set aside the District Judge's order, and released the property from attachment, holding that the appellant acted in good faith and took reasonable care to ascertain the transferor's authority.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal accepted; property released from attachment.
legal_arguments: Section 39(11) of the Industrial Development Bank of Pakistan Ordinance, 1961
Section 41 of the Transfer of Property Act
Case references: PLD 1967 Dacca 203, 1991 SCMR 2513, 1970 SCMR 652
statutes: Industrial Development Bank of Pakistan Ordinance, 1961

witness_statement.Saadi Asmatullah: Testified to purchasing the land in good faith, consulting Revenue Records and Sub-Registrar's office.
witness_statement.Muhammad Aslam Malik: Admitted the mortgage was not registered and not recorded in official departments.

key_issues: Whether the appellant was a bona fide purchaser for consideration.
Effect of unregistered equitable mortgage on property transfer.

maxims.Natural Equity: Section 41 of the Transfer of Property Act is founded upon principles of natural equity.

legal_terms.Equitable Mortgage: A mortgage created without formal registration, relying on deposit of title deeds.
legal_terms.Bona Fide Purchaser: A purchaser who acts in good faith and takes reasonable care to ascertain the transferor's authority.

words_and_phrases.Attachment: Legal seizure of property to secure payment of debt.
words_and_phrases.Good Faith: Acting with honesty and without intent to defraud.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the attachment of property due to an unregistered equitable mortgage. The appellant successfully argued that he was a bona fide purchaser for value, having taken reasonable care to ascertain the transferor's authority. The court accepted the appeal and released the property from attachment.
